perturbation.original_text: 5.2.1 Subject to sub-Clause 5.2.5 below and in the event the Representatives (i) fail to create such committee or (ii) do not agree on an amicable settlement within [*****] from the date the committee referred to in this sub-Clause 5.2 has been created or such longer period as may be agreed upon in writing by the Representatives (the "Amicable Settlement Period"), the Dispute shall be exclusively and finally settled under the Rules and Conciliation of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the "ICC") by an arbitral tribunal composed of three (3) arbitrators; each Party shall then appoint one (1) arbitrator within [*****]from the last day of the Amicable Settlement Period and the third arbitrator, who will act as President, will be appointed by the other two (2) arbitrators. In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with [*****] from the date the last arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.1 Subject to sub-Clause 5.2.5 below and in the event the Representatives (i) fail to create such committee or (ii) do not agree on an amicable settlement within 1 day from the date the committee referred to in this sub-Clause 5.2 has been created or such longer period as may be agreed upon in writing by the Representatives (the "Amicable Settlement Period"), the Dispute shall be exclusively and finally settled under the Rules and Conciliation of Arbitration of the International Chamber of Commerce (the "ICC") by an arbitral tribunal composed of three (3) arbitrators; each Party shall then appoint one (1) arbitrator within 2 days from the last day of the Amicable Settlement Period and the third arbitrator, who will act as President, will be appointed by the other two (2) arbitrators. In case the two (2) arbitrators appointed by the Parties do not agree on this choice with 3 days from the date the last arbitrator is appointed, the third arbitrator will be appointed by the ICC Court.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the timeframes for dispute resolution and arbitrator appointment to extremely short durations (1-3 days) introduces a legal contradiction. While New York law (specified in Clause 5.1) does not explicitly mandate specific timeframes for these processes, such short timeframes could be deemed commercially unreasonable and potentially violate principles of fair dealing and good faith, which are implied in New York contract law. A court could find these deadlines impractical and unenforceable, especially given the complexities of international arbitration.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law, Section 5-1401 (implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing); Principles of contract law regarding reasonableness and enforceability of terms.

perturbation.original_text: 4.6 This Clause 4 shall survive termination or expiry of this Amendment for a period of five (5) years following such End Date.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.6 This Clause 4 shall survive termination or expiry of this Amendment for a period of six (6) months following such End Date.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to six months is a legal contradiction because it may be deemed commercially unreasonable and inadequate to protect sensitive business information, particularly trade secrets. Although New York law doesn't prescribe a specific duration for confidentiality clauses, courts consider the nature of the information and industry standards when determining reasonableness. Six months may be insufficient for information with long-term value or competitive advantage, potentially conflicting with the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing under New York contract law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law, Section 5-1401 (implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing); Trade secret law; Principles of contract law regarding reasonableness of restrictive covenants.

perturbation.original_text: 5.2 Arbitration: in the event of a dispute arising out of or relating to this Amendment, including without limitation disputes regarding the existence, validity or termination of this Amendment (a "Dispute"), either Party may notify such Dispute to the other through service of a written notice (the "Notice of Dispute"). The Parties shall make their reasonable endeavours to settle the Dispute amicably by a committee composed of one (1) management representative of each Party (the "Representatives"). Such committee shall be created by the Parties within [*****] from the date of receipt of the Notice of Dispute.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2 Arbitration: in the event of a dispute arising out of or relating to this Amendment, including without limitation disputes regarding the existence, validity or termination of this Amendment (a "Dispute"), either Party must immediately pursue litigation in Brazil and waive any right to arbitration. The Parties shall immediately cease all communication and not attempt to settle the Dispute amicably.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a legal contradiction by forcing immediate litigation in Brazil, despite the contract specifying New York law and arbitration as the dispute resolution mechanism in the original text. It effectively nullifies the arbitration agreement, which could be challenged under the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) in the United States, specifically in New York, if one party attempts to enforce the arbitration clause. This contradicts the principle that arbitration agreements are generally enforceable and that parties must follow the agreed-upon dispute resolution process.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Arbitration Act (FAA); New York General Obligations Law, Section 5-1401; Contract law principles regarding the enforceability of arbitration agreements.
